summary: The video guides viewers through UX interview preparations with an emphasis on PM rounds, featuring insights, strategies, and personal anecdotes from Justeen.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a display of a grid of video thumbnails, each featuring different topics related to UX design and interviews with product managers. The thumbnails include titles such as "UX Designers & Product Managers Collaboration," "UX Interview with PMs," "UXR UX Collaboration," and "Interview with UXRs." The scene then transitions to a person wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt, sitting in front of a laptop. The individual appears to be speaking, as indicated by their hand gestures and facial expressions. Text overlay on the screen reads, "In this video Interview with product managers," providing context for the content being discussed. The background is a simple indoor setting with a neutral-colored wall and a window with blinds, creating a professional yet casual atmosphere. The video maintains a focus on the speaker, emphasizing their role in discussing the interview with product managers.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with an upbeat, energetic music intro. A male speaker begins with a confident and engaging tone, introducing the topic as a continuation of a UX interview series, briefly referencing the previous episode before stating the focus of the clip: to prepare for the interview rounds with product managers. He expresses that the content will include expectations, potential questions, and strategies to tackle product-related inquiries. He then pauses and asks the audience to get a favorite drink. After noticing his lack of one, he ends the intro with a short phrase that transitions into a "Good morning" greeting.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt, sitting in front of a laptop in a room with a plain wall and a window with blinds. The person greets the audience with a cheerful "Morning!" accompanied by a sun emoji. They gesture with their hands while speaking, and the text "Just FYI" appears on the screen, indicating that the information being shared is for general knowledge. The scene transitions to a white background displaying logos of various companies, divided into two categories: "Yes PM interviews" and "No PM interviews." The companies listed under "Yes PM interviews" include Wing, Chime, Fitbit, Samsara, DoorDash, and others, while those under "No PM interviews" include Niantic, Caffeine, and Snap Inc. The video then shows a comparison between "Product Designer" and "Metric-driven" roles, with a dot indicating the former under "Yes PM interviews" and the latter under "No PM interviews." The person in the blue jacket reappears, continuing to speak and gesture, emphasizing their points. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the person's presentation and the information displayed on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker who has a friendly tone, introducing a discussion about UX onsite interviews in Silicon Valley. He sets expectations and context, noting that not every interview includes a round with product managers. His tone is informational, explaining that it varies by company, and he shares personal experiences. He continues describing a pattern he's observed: roles called "product designers" are more likely to have PM interviews, while design-driven companies might not. The speaker encourages listeners to watch his last video, congratulating them for their willingness to learn new information.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt, seated in front of a laptop. He appears to be speaking, as indicated by his hand gestures and facial expressions. The background is a plain wall with a window covered by blinds. The man is discussing a list of questions displayed on the laptop screen, which includes topics such as problem-solving, product success, business needs, data validation, collaboration, and project challenges. The text on the screen reads "15 PM Questions," suggesting that the man is addressing a set of 15 questions related to project management. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's discussion and the displayed questions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a person speaking in a conversational tone, presenting a list of interview questions and stating their relevance to personal experience. The speaker transitions into describing a specific design problem interview question. The audio concludes with a comment about the question's predictability.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue shirt with a red lanyard around his neck, seated against a plain beige background. He is engaged in a discussion, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. On the right side of the screen, a document with a list of questions is visible, suggesting that the man is responding to these questions. The questions cover topics such as problem-solving, product success, balancing business needs with user needs, data utilization, product shipping, hypothesis validation, collaboration with Me Development Lifecycle, decision-making processes, past challenges, and differences between two entities. The man appears to be explaining his experiences and insights related to these questions. The video progresses with the man continuing his discussion, with the document and questions remaining visible on the screen. The man's gestures and expressions indicate an ongoing conversation, likely aimed at providing detailed answers to the questions listed. The setting remains consistent throughout, with no significant changes in the background or environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing how to measure product success, emphasizing metrics and money. He then moves on to balancing business needs with user needs, using the word "fudge". Next, the speaker discusses using qualitative and quantitative data to inform design decisions, pointing out how product managers are very qualitative and designers are qualitative. There is light background music throughout the clip, featuring a mellow and rhythmic pop sound, providing a calming ambience.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue jacket with a red zipper, seated against a plain beige background. He is engaged in a discussion, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. On the right side of the frame, a computer screen displays a document with a list of questions related to product development and collaboration. The questions include inquiries about the use of qualitative and quantitative data, product validation, collaboration with a 'Me' at different stages, and the difference between a problem and a project. The man appears to be explaining or answering these questions, as indicated by his hand movements and facial expressions. The video progresses with the man continuing his discussion, and the document on the screen remains visible, with the number of questions changing from 5/15 to 6/15, suggesting he is addressing more questions in the sequence. The setting remains consistent throughout, with no significant changes in the environment or background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker asking a question with a somewhat excitable tone about how to form a hypothesis before a product is shipped. He wonders what a hypothesis is based on, whether it is data, patterns, or past history, and discusses projections of an outcome, asking about a $20 increase. Then he asks how to form such a hypothesis. Another question follows up: how do you validate the hypothesis you have? He discusses ways to validate by prototyping and testing. He then ends the discussion by declaring, "I shouldn't spoil it too much." Ambient music plays throughout, with a light and steady rhythm.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue jacket with a red zipper is seen speaking and gesturing with his hands. He is positioned in front of a beige background, and to his right, there is a computer screen displaying a document with a list of questions. The questions are related to design and collaboration processes, such as "How do you use qualitative and quantitative data to inform decisions?" and "How do you collaborate with Me at different stages in a lifecycle?" The document is titled "Search the menu (Option+)" and is numbered 7/15 and later 8/15, indicating it is part of a larger set of questions. The man appears to be explaining or discussing the content of the document, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The setting suggests an interview or a presentation, with the focus on the man and the document on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker posing questions about product development cycle collaboration with product managers, indicating he's possibly leading a discussion or interview. He follows with a description of the topic at hand, advising to discuss workflow with product managers, including designing, feedback, and challenging assumptions. The speaker moves on to a more detailed question about when to use low or high fidelity design, stating it depends on the stages and providing examples ranging from mockups to production-ready prototypes, ending the explanation with an "You see what I'm going, right?".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt, speaking and gesturing with his hands. He appears to be in a professional setting, possibly giving a presentation or interview. The background is neutral, with a beige wall and a blurred audience or setting. On the right side of the screen, there is a text document displayed, containing a list of questions related to collaboration and project development. The questions include inquiries about collaboration with We Me, the development lifecycle, stakeholder collaboration, high-fidelity design, project work, and differences between We Me and design problems. The document also includes a question about generating revenue if Uber is free in San Francisco. The man's gestures and expressions suggest he is explaining or discussing the content of the document. The video progresses with the man continuing his discussion, with the text document remaining visible on the screen. The timestamp on the video changes from 8/15 to 9/15, indicating the passage of time within the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker transitioning into a question about past projects. The speaker outlines how to address solving challenges in collaboration with project managers, highlighting its importance and straightforward nature if the listener has relevant experience. The speaker discusses potential steps for resolving issues such as seeking opinions, talking through problems, prototyping, testing, and walking through past experiences. He mentions that it can be challenging if someone is a new grad with no PM experience. There is a small reference to checking out his previous videos.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt is seen speaking and gesturing with his hands, indicating he is explaining or discussing a topic. The background is plain and beige, focusing attention on the speaker. On the right side of the frame, a computer screen displays a document with text in English, including questions and statements related to design and collaboration. The text includes phrases such as "What's the difference between a design problem and a product," "If you believe your design choice, what's your ideal collaboration," and "If you have 2 months to work on a project, what's your approach?" The document appears to be part of a presentation or discussion, possibly related to design thinking or project management. The date "10/15" is visible in the bottom left corner of the screen, suggesting the recording date. The man's gestures and the text on the screen suggest an interactive and informative session, likely aimed at discussing design principles and collaborative strategies.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the differences between design and product problems, noting that design problems solve user or UI issues, while product problems translate into business needs. He speaks in a didactic, somewhat earnest tone. The audio concludes with a sound effect that resembles a popping noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt, seated against a plain beige background. He is actively engaged in a discussion, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. On the right side of the screen, a split-screen view displays a document with various questions and prompts related to design and collaboration. The text includes inquiries such as "What's the difference between a design problem and a product?" and "If you have 2 months to work on a project, what's your ideal design?" The man appears to be addressing these questions, possibly in a workshop or interview setting. The date "11/15" is visible in the bottom left corner of the screen, indicating the recording date. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man's gestures and the displayed text suggesting an in-depth exploration of design principles and collaborative strategies.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with a man speaking with a conversational tone, giving instructions. He says, "Imagine you're a PM, and I am a designer." He outlines an exercise where the listener is to think like a project manager and work through a problem on the fly. A male speaker finishes, implying that understanding the project manager role will result in success in this exercise. A music track then begins.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue shirt, seated in front of a beige background, engaging in a discussion or presentation. He is seen gesturing with his hands, indicating he is explaining or emphasizing points. On the right side of the frame, a computer screen displays a document with a list of questions, including topics such as Uber's revenue generation in San Francisco, design choices, collaboration, and project timelines. The document also contains a note about expanding the list of questions and advice on conducting interviews. The man appears to be discussing these questions, possibly in the context of preparing for an interview or brainstorming ideas. The date '12/15' is visible in the bottom left corner of the screen, suggesting the recording date. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man actively participating in the conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing how Uber could generate revenue if it were free in San Francisco, questioning who would pay for the operations if users are not. The speaker's tone is inquisitive. He then remarks that the topic is provoking intense thought, calling it "product thinking," and "product intuition."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue shirt with a red lanyard around his neck is seen speaking directly to the camera. He is positioned in front of a computer screen displaying a list of questions, which appear to be related to product management and design. The questions on the screen include topics such as revenue generation, user payment, design choices, collaboration, and working with a design team. The man seems to be discussing these questions, possibly explaining or answering them. The background is plain and neutral, focusing the viewer's attention on the man and the content on the screen. The video progresses with the man continuing his discussion, occasionally gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The text on the screen remains visible throughout, providing context to the conversation. The overall atmosphere is professional and educational, with the man appearing engaged and knowledgeable about the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by asking a question about design choice influence. He then simplifies it by explaining that the question is about influencing and convincing stakeholders. The speaker indicates there are strategies and tactics for this, and references five such things that were mentioned in a previous video. The tone of the speaker is casual. At the end, he encourages listeners to find more info in the description.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue shirt is seen speaking and gesturing with his hands, indicating he is explaining or discussing a topic. The background is a plain, light-colored wall, providing a neutral setting that keeps the focus on the speaker. To the right of the man, there is a computer screen displaying a document with a list of questions, suggesting that the discussion is related to these questions. The text on the screen includes questions such as "If the menu is free in San Francisco, how can the user generate revenue?" and "If you believe your design choice is better than the idea, what would you do?" These questions appear to be related to product management or design thinking, as they involve strategic thinking and decision-making. The document also mentions a 45-minute interview routine with a product manager, indicating that the man might be discussing interview preparation or strategies for product management roles. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the document, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's actions, emphasizing the importance of the content being discussed.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker transitioning into the topic of ideal collaborations between PM and design. The speaker highlights the common knowledge that should be possessed from PM work experiences and offers possible ways to improve the collaboration in that relationship. This includes being more supportive, challenging, and trusting. The speaker wraps up the point by explaining that there are more possibilities. The audio clip concludes with the speaker stating that the question is easy.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue shirt, seated against a plain background, engaging in a discussion or presentation. He is seen gesturing with his hands, emphasizing points as he speaks. On the right side of the screen, a document is displayed, containing a list of questions and answers related to design choices, collaboration, and product management. The text is in English, with some phrases highlighted in bold, such as "If you believe your design choice is right to do so, please believe in your idea" and "What's your idea collaboration between me and design?" The document also includes a section titled "Let's switch perspectives," which discusses the product management setup and organization. The man appears to be explaining or elaborating on the content of the document, using hand gestures to illustrate his points. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's presentation and the displayed document.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker posing a hypothetical project management question, inquiring about the difference in approach between a two-month and a two-week timeline and who would be involved. His tone is thoughtful and inquisitive. Following this question, he mentions having received it before. The clip concludes with him identifying this as his 15th query.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue jacket and a black shirt is seated in front of a laptop, engaging in a conversation or presentation. He uses expressive hand gestures to emphasize his points, with his hands raised and fingers spread wide. The background is a plain, light-colored wall, and the lighting is warm, creating a cozy atmosphere. The man appears to be speaking directly to the camera, maintaining eye contact and occasionally looking down at the laptop screen. Towards the end of the video, a text overlay appears at the bottom of the screen, reading "Want a copy? Drop a comment + email (justenvlogger@gmail) 😊" in English, inviting viewers to request a copy of the content by commenting and emailing the provided address. The man's gestures become more animated as he continues to speak, indicating a lively and engaging discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, his tone informative and clear, stating, "I need one more hand actually." He then mentions PM questions and the need to expand a list. He offers a copy of a worksheet, instructing the listener to comment or email for it. A brief, upbeat musical interlude plays in the background, creating a light mood.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a blue jacket and black shirt sitting in front of a laptop, engaging in a conversation or presentation. He uses hand gestures to emphasize his points, with the background showing a plain wall and a window with blinds. Text appears on the screen, including phrases like "Your intro," "Their questions," and "Their intro," suggesting a discussion about introductions and questions. The man appears focused and animated, with the text "*45 mins only*" indicating a time constraint. The setting is simple and professional, with the man's gestures and the text providing context to the conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker calmly explaining that despite preparing for many questions, in a real interview, fewer questions are usually asked due to the time needed for elaboration. He emphasizes considering the introductions, questions, and time needed for detailed answers, implying limited time. He concludes by advising listeners not to panic about answering numerous questions. Then the clip transitions to a whooshing sound, followed by the speaker's announcement of a change in perspective.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a blue jacket and black shirt, seated in front of a laptop, gesturing as he speaks. The background is a plain wall with a window covered by blinds. The scene transitions to a black screen with white text reading "1/5 Can you work under their product org setup?" followed by another black screen with "2/5 Can you see big pictures (business) and small details (UIUX design)?" The video then shows the man in black and white, reading a book while looking at the laptop. Subsequent frames display black screens with white text asking "3/5 Can you work with the pros and cons of the product?" and "4/5 How did you influence PMs, if at all?" The video concludes with the man in color, still seated in front of the laptop, gesturing as he speaks.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker enthusiastically discussing interview advice for product managers, outlining five key considerations: the candidate's ability to work efficiently in a product organization, their grasp of both the big picture and small details, their understanding of platform strengths and weaknesses, their stance on opinions, and overall compatibility. A brief, ambiguous noise is then heard before the speaker continues, questioning if he can work with the candidate. The audio is interspersed with background music, creating a modern mood.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a blue jacket with a black shirt underneath is seated in front of a laptop, engaging in a conversation or presentation. He is positioned in a room with a plain, light-colored wall and a window with closed blinds in the background. The man uses hand gestures to emphasize his points, occasionally pointing to the laptop screen, which is not visible in the frames provided. The lighting in the room is warm, creating a cozy atmosphere. Throughout the video, the man's facial expressions and gestures suggest he is actively communicating, possibly explaining or discussing a topic. The camera remains focused on him, capturing his upper body and the immediate surroundings, with no significant changes in the environment or background details.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker explaining that answering questions fully and thoroughly will lead to a "yes" in five areas, increasing the likelihood of a PM voting for the listener. He suggests celebrating with a comment, followed by a triumphant, short musical flourish, perhaps indicating success or accomplishment.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a blue jacket and black shirt sitting in front of a laptop, engaging in a conversation or presentation. He uses hand gestures to emphasize his points, with a plain wall and a window with blinds in the background. Text appears on the screen, reading "Work with PMs," indicating the topic of discussion. The scene transitions to a split-screen format, with the man on the right and two video thumbnails on the left, labeled "Woah so insightful!" and "Hmm good point!" The thumbnails suggest viewer reactions to the content. A 'like' button with 654 likes and a 'subscribe' button appear at the bottom, encouraging viewer engagement. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the two video thumbnails, maintaining the call to action for viewers to interact with the content.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with upbeat, electronic music creating a cheerful, motivational mood. A male speaker with an enthusiastic tone presents potential interview questions for product managers, discussing collaboration with engineers and design thinking.  He directs listeners to related videos and encourages likes, subscriptions, and continued design thinking. The upbeat electronic music returns, closing the clip.
